description: 1780-90; compare Scots dink (“neatly dressed, trim”) (of obscure origin); sense shift perhaps: trim > dainty > small > insignificant;  +‎ -y.

entries.meaning: (informal, Britain) Tiny and cute; small and attractive.
examples: How do you like my hat? That one you had on in church yesterday was real dinky.

entries.meaning: (informal, US) Tiny and insignificant; small and undesirable.
examples: They stayed in a dinky hotel room, but they had a great trip.

entries.meaning: (slang) A person in a relationship with double income and no kids
